senses.definition: to be spread out in a particular place

senses.definition: to be in a particular position during a competition
examples: + adv./prep. Thompson is lying in fourth place.
+ adj. After five games the German team are lying second.

senses.definition: to be the original cause of something, especially something unpleasant

senses.definition: to cause somebody/something to feel uncomfortable or anxious

senses.definition: to avoid mentioning a subject or something that happened in the past, in order to avoid any problems or arguments

senses.definition: to be placed on view in a public place before being buried
to hide, waiting to surprise, attack or catch somebody
examples: He was surrounded by reporters who had been lying in wait for him.

senses.definition: to try not to attract attention to yourself
to find out about a situation
examples: Let's wait and see how the land lies before we do anything.

senses.definition: to accept an offensive remark or act without protesting or reacting
you must accept the results of your actions
to say or write something that you know is not true

senses.definition: to say something that is not true at all

senses.definition: to get yourself into or out of a situation by lying

senses.definition: to die. People say ‘depart this life’ to avoid saying ‘die’.

senses.definition: to spend the last part of your life in a particular state or place
examples: He ended his days in poverty.

senses.definition: the details about sex and about how babies are born, especially as told to children

senses.definition: as hard or as fast as possible

senses.definition: having a lot of energy

senses.definition: to hold somebody/something very tightly because you are afraid
to be very lucky in dangerous situations

seeming to move or function by itself without a person touching or working it

senses.definition: the person somebody loves more than any other

senses.definition: a basic food, especially bread
to kill somebody

senses.definition: to risk being killed

senses.definition: used when you are disappointed about something but know that you must accept it

senses.definition: having a range of different experiences makes life more interesting

senses.definition: the typical pattern of behaviour of a person or group

senses.definition: in a bad situation you must not give up hope because there is always a chance that it will improve

senses.definition: the pressure of air moving upwards on an aircraft when flying

senses.definition: to raise somebody/something or be raised to a higher position or level

senses.definition: to get richer or make somebody richer, especially by taking unfair advantage of a situation or by being dishonest

examples: If looks could kill, she thought, seeing the expression that came over his face when he saw her, she’d be dead on the pavement.

senses.definition: to consider a problem or possibility very carefully and without hurrying
examples: We need to take a long, hard look at all the options.

senses.definition: to turn your eyes in a particular direction
examples: Look closely and tell me what you see.
If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.
‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll look and see.’
Look! I'm sure that's Jennifer Lawrence!
Don't look now, but there's someone staring at you!
look at somebody/something She looked at me and smiled.
look + adv./prep. I got up and looked out of the window.
She looked across to the other side of the room.
If you look carefully you can just see our house from here.
She looked at me and smiled.

Watch what I do, then you try.
In the evening we went to see a movie.
People came from all over the world to view her work.

He looked longingly at the food on the table.

senses.definition: to try to find somebody/something

senses.definition: to pay attention to something

senses.definition: to seem; to appear
examples: How do I look?
+ adj. You look great!
The garden looks nice.

look like somebody/something That looks like an interesting book.
look like somebody/something to somebody It doesn't look like fun to me.
+ noun You made me look a complete fool!

look as if…/as though… You look as though you slept badly.

senses.definition: to seem likely to happen or be true
examples: It looks like rain (= it looks as if it's going to rain).

look to somebody as if…/as though… It looks to me as though the company is in real trouble.
look like… (informal) They don’t look like they’re trying to win.
look to somebody like… (informal) It looks to me like they have a plan.

senses.definition: to face a particular direction

senses.definition: used in a shop to say that you are not ready to buy something

senses.definition: to try to find ways of doing something
examples: The government is looking to reduce inflation.

senses.definition: to be considered bad behaviour or bad manners
examples: It looks bad not going to your own brother's wedding.

senses.definition: to show that something bad might happen
examples: He's had another heart attack; things are looking bad for him, I'm afraid.

senses.definition: to show success or that something good might happen
examples: This year's sales figures are looking good.

senses.definition: used to protest about something
examples: Now look here, it wasn't my fault.

senses.definition: used to give an example that proves what you are saying or makes it clearer
examples: Look how lazy we've become.

senses.definition: used to say that something is exactly what somebody needs and so they do not need to consider any other options

senses.definition: to look at somebody in a careful or critical way
to (not) have your normal healthy appearance
examples: You're not looking yourself today (= you look tired or ill/sick).

senses.definition: to become more and more successful
examples: Her first novel was published in 2007 and since then she hasn't looked back.

senses.definition: not attractive
judging by the appearance of somebody/something
examples: To look at him you'd never think he was nearly fifty.

senses.definition: not securely fixed where it should be; able to become separated from something

senses.definition: not fitting closely

senses.definition: not tightly packed together; not solid or hard
examples: loose soil

senses.definition: not strictly organized or managed

senses.definition: not in any player’s control

senses.definition: having too much liquid in it

senses.definition: suddenly there was a lot of noise, arguing, fighting, etc.

senses.definition: to remain calm; to not worry

senses.definition: to talk too much, especially about things that are private

senses.definition: to make a noise or remark, especially in a loud or sudden way

senses.definition: to treat somebody/something in a way that shows that you feel no responsibility or respect for them

senses.definition: a title used for some high official positions in the UK

examples: a feudal lord
the lord of the manor

senses.definition: a title used to refer to God or Christ
examples: Love the Lord with all your heart.

senses.definition: a title used to refer to Christ
(in the UK) the part of Parliament whose members are not elected by the people of the country
examples: The Lords has/have not yet reached a decision.

senses.definition: the building where members of the House of Lords meet
very drunk
used to show that you are surprised, annoyed or worried about something
examples: Good Lord, what have you done to your hair!

senses.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying
examples: Lord knows, I tried to teach her.

senses.definition: used to say that you do not know the answer to something
examples: ‘Why did she say that?’ ‘Lord knows!’

senses.definition: any particular year after the birth of Christ
a large vehicle for carrying heavy loads by road
examples: a lorry driver
a lorry load of frozen fish
by lorry Emergency food supplies were brought in by lorry.

senses.definition: goods that fell off the back of a lorry were probably stolen. People say or accept that they came ‘off the back of a lorry’ to avoid saying or asking where they really came from.

examples: I've lost my keys.

senses.definition: to have something/somebody taken away from you, especially as a result of an accident, dying, etc.

senses.definition: to have to give up something; to fail to keep something/somebody

to lose a race/an election/a battle/a war
lose to somebody We lost to a stronger team.
lose by something He lost by less than 100 votes.

senses.definition: money that has been lost by a business or an organization

senses.definition: used to say that you would very much like something
examples: would love to do something Come on Rory, the kids would love to hear you sing.
I haven't been to Brazil, but I'd love to go.
would love somebody/something to do something I'd love her to come and live with us.
would love something ‘Coffee?’ ‘I'd love one, thanks.’
(informal) would love for somebody/something to do something We would love for you to contact us.
I'd love for my kids to learn another language.

senses.definition: used to say that you must go, although you would like to stay longer
examples: Well, time to love you and leave you.

senses.definition: beautiful; attractive
examples: She looked particularly lovely that night.
He has a lovely voice.
You've got lovely eyes.
We travelled through some lovely countryside.
She's got an absolutely lovely face.
She looked stunningly beautiful that night.
She’s got a very pretty face.
He was described as ‘tall, dark and handsome’.
She’s a very attractive woman.
She looked particularly lovely that night.
She arrived with a very good-looking man.
You look gorgeous!

senses.definition: very pleasant; wonderful
examples: ‘Can I get you anything?’ ‘A cup of tea would be lovely.’
What a lovely surprise!
How lovely to see you!
Isn't it a lovely day?
We've had a lovely time.
It's a lovely old farm.
It's been lovely having you here.
(ironic) You've got yourself into a lovely mess, haven't you?
to smell/taste/sound lovely
We had a wonderful time last night.
The weather was absolutely wonderful.
What a lovely day! (= the weather is very good)
It’s been lovely having you here.
a delightful little fishing village
The cool water felt lovely after being in the hot sun.
Your idea of a day on the beach sounds lovely.
a hauntingly lovely melody
It was a lovely evening—calm and still.
The weather here is lovely.

senses.definition: very kind, generous and friendly
examples: Her mother was a lovely woman.
He is a lovely little boy.
She is a lovely old lady and always full of laughter.

senses.definition: used when you are emphasizing that something is good because of the quality mentioned
examples: It's lovely and warm in here.

senses.definition: not high or tall; not far above the ground
examples: a low wall/building/table
The fence is too low.
a low range of hills
low clouds
flying at low altitude
The sun was low in the sky.

senses.definition: at or near the bottom of something
examples: low back pain
the lower slopes of the mountain
in the low 20s, 30s, etc. temperatures in the low 20s (= no higher than 21–23°)

senses.definition: not high at the neck
examples: a dress with a low neckline
The neckline was much lower than she was used to.
The dress had a V-neck and a very low back.
tight sweaters and low-neck shirts

senses.definition: below the usual or average amount, level or value
examples: a low level of unemployment
lower prices/costs
the lowest rates of interest for 40 years
the lowest temperature ever recorded
low-income families
a low-cost airline
There is a low risk of failure.
Incomes are significantly lower than in other parts of the country.
areas with relatively low unemployment
low in something This yogurt is very low in fat.
The failure rate is extremely low.
The government wants to keep taxes low.
historically low marriage statistics
Their ready meals are low in sugar and salt.

senses.definition: below the usual water level
examples: The reservoir was low after the long drought.

senses.definition: having a reduced amount or not enough of something
examples: Our supplies are running low (= we only have a little left).
Our stocks of food were getting low.
A warning light flashes when the battery is low.
low on something They were low on fuel.

senses.definition: below the usual or expected standard
examples: Students with the lowest scores retook the test.
low marks/grades
a low standard of living
Much of the work was of a very low standard.
These measures will lead to a lower quality of life for many older people.

senses.definition: below other people or things in importance or status
examples: lower forms of life (= creatures with a very simple structure)
jobs with low status
Training was given a very low priority.

senses.definition: not very good
examples: She has a very low opinion of her own abilities.

senses.definition: not high; not loud
examples: The cello is lower than the violin.
They were speaking in low voices.
Keep your voice low.

senses.definition: weak or depressed; with very little energy
examples: I'm feeling really low.
They were in low spirits.
I think he got a bit low when he had the flu.

senses.definition: not honest
examples: He mixes with some pretty low types.

senses.definition: not bright
examples: The lights were low and romance was in the air.

senses.definition: if a vehicle is in low gear, it travels at a slower speed in relation to the speed of the engine
produced with the tongue in the lowest possible position
in a poor state; worse than usual
examples: Morale among teachers is at a low ebb.

senses.definition: to lose your wealth or your high position in society
the amount of attention somebody/something has from the public
examples: This issue has had a high profile in recent months.
I advised her to keep a low profile for the next few days (= not to attract attention).
The story was given a low profile in today's papers.

senses.definition: if somebody is laid low by/with an injury or illness, they feel very weak and are unable to do much
people who are not respected at all because they are not honest, moral or important at all
in or into a low position, not far above the ground
examples: to crouch/bend low
He bowed low and said, ‘I am your humble servant.’
a plane flying low over the town
low-flying aircraft
The sun sank lower towards the horizon.
Birds swooped low over their heads.
The keeper dived low to save the shot.

senses.definition: in or into a position near the bottom of something
examples: a window set low in the wall
The candles were burning low.

senses.definition: at a level below what is usual or expected
examples: low-priced goods
a low-powered PC
a very low-scoring game
low-hanging clouds/branches
Investors are told to buy low and sell high.

senses.definition: not high; not loudly
examples: He's singing an octave lower than the rest of us.
Can you turn the music lower—you'll wake the baby.

senses.definition: everywhere
examples: I've searched high and low for my purse.

senses.definition: to try not to attract attention to yourself
to have such low moral standards that you do something very bad
examples: Stealing from your friends? How could you sink so low?
I can't believe that anyone would sink to such depths.
With this article the newspaper has sunk to a new low.

senses.definition: to drop your moral standards far enough to do something bad or unpleasant
examples: She was unwilling to believe anyone would stoop so low as to steal a ring from a dead woman's finger.

senses.definition: a low level or point; a low figure
examples: The temperature reached a record low in London last night.
The government's popularity has hit a new low.
at a low The yen is at an all-time low against the dollar.
Interest rates are at historic lows.
to a low to sink/plunge/plummet to a new low
to fall/drop to a five-year low

senses.definition: a very difficult time in somebody’s life or career
examples: The break-up of her marriage marked an all-time low in her life.
We all experience highs and lows in life.

senses.definition: an area of low pressure in the atmosphere
examples: Another low is moving in from the Atlantic.

senses.definition: to behave in a worse way than ever before
examples: The government has stooped to an all-time low with this policy.
Reality TV has sunk to new lows.

senses.definition: to reduce something or to become less in value, quality, etc.
examples: lower something He lowered his voice to a whisper.
This drug is used to lower blood pressure.
to lower the rate/cost/price/level of something
Her voice lowered as she spoke.
The company may be forced to lower prices in order to stay competitive.
a proposal to lower the voting age to 16
The company has lowered its expectations for profits this year.
We are not prepared to lower our academic standards.
Mild exercise three times a week significantly lowers your risk of cancer.
The drives were allowed to idle until the temperatures lowered and stabilized.

senses.definition: to let or make something/somebody go down
examples: lower something He had to lower his head to get through the door.
She lowered her newspaper and looked around.
lower something/somebody + adv./prep. They lowered him down the cliff on a rope.
The coffin is lowered into the grave and covered with earth.
Cristina blushed and quickly lowered her eyes.
He carefully lowered the sleeping child onto the bed.
She lowered herself into the driver's seat.

senses.definition: to set a new, lower standard of quality or performance
examples: In the current economic climate we may need to lower the bar on quotas.

senses.definition: to behave in a way that makes other people respect you less
examples: I wouldn't lower myself by working for him.

senses.definition: to expect more/less from a situation
examples: If they can’t afford such a big house, they’ll just have to lower their sights a little.
After failing to get into university, he lowered his sights and got a job in a shop.

senses.definition: to increase/decrease the amount of excitement, emotion, etc. in a situation
examples: His angry refusal to agree raised the temperature of the meeting.
The government tried to lower the political temperature by agreeing to some of the demands.

senses.definition: good things that happen to you by chance, not because of your own efforts or abilities
examples: with (any) luck With any luck, we'll be home before dark.
(British English) With a bit of luck, we'll finish on time.
luck with doing something So far I have had no luck with finding a job.
luck with something I'm not having much luck with buses.
luck with somebody I never had much luck (= had a successful relationship) with women.
I could hardly believe my luck when he said yes.
It was a stroke of luck that we found you.
by luck By sheer luck nobody was hurt in the explosion.
The only goal of the match came more by luck than judgement.
We wish her luck in her new career.
She wears a red bracelet to bring her luck.
in luck You're in luck (= lucky)—there's one ticket left.
out of luck You're out of luck. She's not here.
What a piece of luck!
Finally my luck ran out and they caught me trying to climb the outer wall.
I haven't had much luck recently.
I thought I was going to miss the train but luck was on my side.
If our luck holds, we should win.
You make your own luck in business.

senses.definition: chance; the force that causes good or bad things to happen to people
examples: to have good/bad luck
I put the loss of the money down to pure bad luck.
luck with something We had horrible luck with the weather.
In many cultures the colour blue is believed to bring good luck.
myths based on the idea that owls bring bad luck
She dared not trust to luck that nobody would see her.
This ring has always brought me good luck.
The results could simply be due to chance.
They met through a series of strange coincidences.
Their early arrival was just an accident.
Fate decreed that she would never reach America.
I believe there’s some force guiding us—call it God, destiny or fate.
By ill luck, my flight had been cancelled.
He applied for two more jobs, sure his luck was about to change.
The next bus wasn't for an hour, so I decided to try my luck at hitchhiking.
It was rotten luck to be ill on the day of the interview.
More bad luck struck last week.
This ring has always brought me good luck.
My grandparents emigrated to Canada to try their luck there.

senses.definition: used to ask somebody if they have been successful with something
examples: ‘Any luck?’ ‘No, they're all too busy to help.’

senses.definition: in the way that chance decides what will happen
examples: As luck would have it, the train was late.

senses.definition: used to express sympathy for somebody
examples: Bad luck, Helen—you played very well.
It's hard luck on him that he wasn't chosen.
What rotten luck it had to happen now!

senses.definition: to have no money because of a period of bad luck
examples: In the movie they play two jazz musicians who are down on their luck.

senses.definition: used to wish somebody success with something
examples: The best of luck with your exams.
Good luck! I hope it goes well.
(ironic) ‘I'm going to try giving up social media for a year.’ ‘Good luck with that (= I don't think you will succeed).’

senses.definition: used to encourage somebody who has not been successful at something
examples: Never mind— better luck next time.
If you didn't win a prize, better luck next time.

senses.definition: because you believe it will bring you good luck, or because this is a traditional belief
examples: Take something blue. It's for luck.
I always carry it with me, just for luck.

senses.definition: for no particular reason
examples: I gave the mixture one more stir for luck.

senses.definition: used to say that you do not mind what somebody does as it does not affect you, but you hope they will be successful
examples: It's not something I would care to try myself but if she wants to, good luck to her.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that you feel sorry for them
examples: ‘Failed again, I'm afraid.’ ‘Oh, hard luck.’

senses.definition: used to show you are not surprised something bad has happened to you, because you are not often lucky
examples: Just my luck to arrive after they had left.
Just my luck to get the broken chair!

senses.definition: used to say that somebody has been lucky or successful
examples: On a Sunday I didn’t expect to find him at his desk but my luck was in.

senses.definition: the fact that chance decides something, in a way that you cannot control
examples: To a large extent the life you have depends on who your parents were; it’s just the luck of the biological draw.

senses.definition: used to show that you are disappointed because something you were hoping for did not happen
examples: ‘Were you chosen for the team?’ ‘No such luck!’

senses.definition: when you take pot luck, you choose something or go somewhere without knowing very much about it, but hope that it will be good, pleasant, etc.
examples: It's pot luck whether you get good advice or not.
You're welcome to stay to supper, but you'll have to take pot luck (= eat whatever is available).

senses.definition: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past
examples: You didn't get caught last time, but don't push your luck!

senses.definition: used to show sympathy for somebody that something bad that has happened to
examples: ‘I failed by one point.’ ‘That's tough luck.’

senses.definition: used to show that you do not feel sorry for somebody who has a problem
examples: ‘If you take the car, I won't be able to go out.’ ‘Tough luck!’

senses.definition: to do something that involves risk or luck, hoping to succeed
examples: My grandparents emigrated to Canada to try their luck there.

senses.definition: used to show that you are disappointed about something
examples: I shall have to miss the party, worse luck!

senses.definition: having good luck
examples: lucky to do something His friend was killed and he knows he is lucky to be alive.
She was lucky enough to be chosen for the team.
lucky (that) You were lucky (that) you spotted the danger in time.
In terms of my career I feel incredibly lucky.
You can think yourself lucky you didn't get mugged.
She counted herself lucky that she still had a job.
Mark is one of the lucky ones—he at least has somewhere to sleep.
the lucky winners
He was among the lucky ones who escaped with only minor injuries.
That was just plain lucky.
We've been pretty lucky so far.

senses.definition: being the result of good luck
examples: lucky for somebody that… It was lucky for us that we were able to go.
lucky for somebody Lucky for her, a police car was passing.
lucky (that) It is lucky (that) neither was killed in the accident.
That was the luckiest escape of my life.
a lucky guess
A lucky find on the edge of the Cotswolds is helping archaeologists discover what life was like in Roman Britain.
I had a lucky break when I left school getting a job on local radio.

senses.definition: bringing good luck
examples: a lucky charm
The team thinks of me as their lucky mascot.

senses.definition: to have good luck
examples: She hopes that some day she'll get lucky and win the jackpot.

senses.definition: to meet somebody new and have sex with them
examples: Mike's hoping to get lucky tonight.

senses.definition: used to show that you think somebody is lucky to have something, be able to do something, etc.
examples: ‘I'm off to Paris.’ ‘Lucky you!’

senses.definition: to have good luck
examples: We certainly struck it lucky with the weather.

senses.definition: to feel very grateful and lucky about something
examples: Just thank your lucky stars you weren’t in the house at the time.

senses.definition: used when you have failed to do something twice and hope that you will succeed the third time
used to tell somebody that something that they are expecting probably will not happen
examples: ‘I was hoping to get a ticket for Saturday.’ ‘You'll be lucky.’

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that they will probably not get what they are hoping for, and may not deserve it
a meal eaten in the middle of the day
examples: She's gone to lunch.
I'm ready for some lunch.
I always eat/have lunch at my desk.
for lunch What shall we have for lunch?
over lunch Lopez suggested they meet over lunch (= at or during lunchtime).
We serve hot and cold lunches.
a one-hour lunch break
Let's do lunch (= have lunch together).
Christmas/Sunday lunch
a picnic/buffet lunch
We had a pub lunch (= lunch in a pub).
I make sure my kids have a hot school dinner, not just a packed lunch.
a cream tea.
What time do the kids have their tea?
Come and have a spot of lunch with me.
Do you want to grab some lunch?
I helped wash up the lunch things.
He fixed lunch for the whole family.
The lunch crowd was filtering in slowly.
The restaurant offers a £20 set lunch.
The society's annual lunch will be held next Wednesday.
The tour includes a lunch stop.
We went for a sandwich lunch at the local bar.

senses.definition: behaving in a strange or confused way
used to say that it is not possible to get something for nothing
either of the two organs in the chest that you use for breathing
examples: Her father died of lung cancer.
Obesity can raise the risk of lung disease.
He will need a lung transplant if he is going to survive.
Some of these substances are known to damage lung tissue.
Coughing clears the lungs of mucus.
She felt the sun on her skin and fresh air in her lungs.
He's been hospitalized for a blood clot in his lung.
(humorous) She has a fine pair of lungs! (= she can sing or shout loudly)
Her lungs ached from the exertion.
I opened the window and filled my lungs with cool fresh air.
Lungs bursting, she flew across the finish line.
The smoke was burning his lungs.
These particles are breathed into the lungs.
Your heart and lungs have to work harder if you're overweight.
Eliminating certain foods shown to provoke asthma can lead to improved lung function.

senses.definition: expensive and of very high quality
examples: a luxury hotel/car/apartment
luxury goods
expensive luxury brands/items

senses.definition: the fact of enjoying special and expensive things, particularly food and drink, clothes and places
examples: a life of unimaginable luxury
in luxury Now we'll be able to live in luxury for the rest of our lives.
It was sheer luxury to step into a hot bath.
Silk sheets added the final touch of luxury.
The resort offers luxury on a grand scale.
We can't afford such luxury.

senses.definition: a thing that is expensive and pleasant but not essential
examples: small luxuries like chocolate and flowers
I love having a long, hot bath—it's one of life's little luxuries.
It was a luxury if you had a washing machine in those days.
A comfortable bed to sleep in is a luxury that we take for granted.
He missed the simple luxuries of life, like regular meals.
She's had every luxury in life.
We can't afford luxuries.

senses.definition: a pleasure or an advantage that you do not often have
examples: We had the luxury of being able to choose from four good candidates for the job.
He had the luxury of spending time at his family's summer home.
We enjoyed the luxury of an expensive restaurant meal.

senses.definition: in easy, comfortable conditions, and enjoying the advantages of being rich
examples: We spent two weeks in the hotel living in the lap of luxury.
